'''Single molecule fluorescence resonance energy transfer''' (or '''smFRET''') is a [[Biophysics|biophysical]] [[Outline of biophysics#Biophysical techniques|technique]] used to measure distances at the 1-10 [[nanometer]] scale in single [[molecule]]s, typically [[biomolecule]]s. It is an application of [[Förster resonance energy transfer|FRET]] wherein a pair of donor and acceptor [[fluorophores]] are excited and detected on a single molecule level. In contrast to "ensemble FRET" which provides the FRET signal of a high number of molecules, single-molecule FRET is able to resolve the FRET signal of each individual molecule.
==Methodology== Single molecule FRET measurements are typically performed on [[fluorescence microscope]]s, either using surface-immobilized or freely-diffusing molecules. Single FRET pairs are illuminated using intense light sources, typically [[lasers]], in order to generate sufficient fluorescence signal to enable single molecule detection. [[Wide-field multiphoton microscopy]] is typically combined with [[Total internal reflection fluorescence microscope|total internal reflection fluorescence microscope (TIRF)]]. This selectively excites FRET pairs on the surface of the measurement chamber and rejects noise from the bulk of the sample. Conversely, [[confocal microscopy]] minimizes background by focusing the fluorescence light onto a pinhole to reject out of focus light.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moerner|first=W. E.|last2=Fromm|first2=David P.|date=2003-08-01|title=Methods of single-molecule fluorescence spectroscopy and microscopy|url=http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/rsi/74/8/10.1063/1.1589587|journal=Review of Scientific Instruments|volume=74|issue=8|pages=3597–3619|doi=10.1063/1.1589587|issn=0034-6748}}</ref> The confocal volume has a diameter of around 220 nm, and therefore it must be scanned across if an image of the sample is needed. With confocal excitation, it is possible to measure much deeper into the sample than when using TIRF. Fluorescence signal is detected either using ultra sensitive [[Charge-coupled device|CCD]] or [[Active pixel sensor|scientific CMOS cameras]] for wide field microscopy or [[Single-photon avalanche diode|SPADs]] for confocal microscopy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Michalet|first=X.|last2=Colyer|first2=R. A.|last3=Scalia|first3=G.|last4=Ingargiola|first4=A.|last5=Lin|first5=R.|last6=Millaud|first6=J. E.|last7=Weiss|first7=S.|last8=Siegmund|first8=Oswald H. W.|last9=Tremsin|first9=Anton S.|date=2013-02-05|title=Development of new photon-counting detectors for single-molecule fluorescence microscopy|url=http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/368/1611/20120035|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|language=en|volume=368|issue=1611|pages=20120035|doi=10.1098/rstb.2012.0035|issn=0962-8436|pmc=3538434|pmid=23267185}}</ref> Once the single molecule intensities vs. time are available the FRET efficiency can be computed for each FRET pair as a function of time and thereby it is possible to follow kinetic events on the single molecule scale and to build FRET [[histograms]] showing the distribution of states in each molecule. However, data from many FRET pairs must be recorded and combined in order to obtain general information about a sample.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ha|first=T.|last2=Enderle|first2=T.|last3=Ogletree|first3=D. F.|last4=Chemla|first4=D. S.|last5=Selvin|first5=P. R.|last6=Weiss|first6=S.|date=1996-06-25|title=Probing the interaction between two single molecules: fluorescence resonance energy transfer between a single donor and a single acceptor|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/93/13/6264|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=93|issue=13|pages=6264–6268|doi=10.1073/pnas.93.13.6264|issn=0027-8424|pmid=8692803|pmc=39010}}</ref>
=== Surface-Immobilized === In surface-immobilized experiments, biomolecules labeled with fluorescent tags are bound to the surface of the coverglass and images of fluorescence are acquired (typically by a [[Charge-coupled device|CCD]] or [[Active pixel sensor|scientific CMOS]] cameras).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kastantin|first=Mark|last2=Schwartz|first2=Daniel K.|date=2011-12-27|title=Connecting Rare DNA Conformations and Surface Dynamics Using Single-Molecule Resonance Energy Transfer|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/nn2035389|journal=ACS Nano|volume=5|issue=12|pages=9861–9869|doi=10.1021/nn2035389|issn=1936-0851|pmc=3246573|pmid=21942411}}</ref> Data collection with cameras will produce movies of the specimen which must be processed to derive the single molecule intensities with time.
An advantage of surface-immobilized experiments is that many molecules can be observed in parallel for an extended period of time until [[photobleaching]] (typically 1-30 s). This allows to conveniently study transitions taking place on slow time scales. A disadvantage is represented by the additional biochemical modifications needed to link molecules to the surface and the perturbations that the surface can potentially exert on the molecular activity. In addition, the maximum time resolution of single-molecule intensities is limited by the camera acquisition time (> 1 ms).
=== Freely-Diffusing === SmFRET can also be used to study the [[Conformational isomerism|conformations]] of molecules freely diffusing in a liquid sample. In freely-diffusing smFRET experiments (or diffusion-based smFRET), the same biomolecules are free to diffuse in solution while being excited by a small excitation volume (usually a [[Airy disk|diffraction-limited spot]]). Bursts of photons due a single-molecule crossing the excitation spot are acquired with [[Single-photon avalanche diode|SPAD]] detectors. The confocal spot is usually fixed in a given position (no scanning happens, and no image is acquired). Instead, the fluorescence photons emitted by individual molecules crossing the excitation volume are recorded and accumulated in order to build a distribution of different populations present in the sample. Depending on the complexity of this distribution, acquisition times varies from ~5 min to several hours.
A distinctive advantage of setups employing SPAD detectors is that they are not limited by a "frame rate" or a fixed integration time like when using cameras. In fact, unlike cameras, SPADs produce a pulse every time a photon is detected, while an additional electronics is needed to "timestamps" each pulse with 10-50 ns resolution. The high time resolution of confocal single-molecule FRET measurements allows to potentially detect dynamics on time scales as low as 10 μs. However, detecting "slow" transitions on timescales longer than the diffusion time (typically ~1 ms), is more difficult than in surface-immobilized experiments and generally requires much longer acquisitions.
Normally, the fluorescent emission of both donor and acceptor fluorophores is detected by two independent detectors and the FRET signal is computed from the ratio of intensities in the two channels. Some setup configurations further split each spectral channel (donor or acceptor) in two orthogonal polarizations (therefore requiring 4 detectors) and are able to measure both FRET and [[fluorescence anisotropy]] at the same time. In other configurations, 3 or 4 spectral channels are acquired at the same time in order to measure multiple FRET pairs at the same time. Both [[Laser|CW or pulsed lasers]] can be used as excitation source. When using pulsed lasers, a suitable acquisition hardware can measure the photon arrival time with respect to the last laser pulse with picosecond resolution, in the so-called [[time-correlated single photon counting]] (TCSPC) acquisition. In this configuration each photon is characterized by a macro-time (i.e. a coarse 10-50 ns timestamp) and a micro-time (i.e. delay with respect the last laser pulse). The latter can be used to extract lifetime information and obtain the FRET signal.
== Advantages of smFRET == [[File:SmFRET vs. ensemble FRET.png|thumb|Ensemble FRET analysis of a heterogeneous population]] SmFRET allows for a more precise analysis of [[heterogeneous]] populations and has a few advantages when compared to ensemble FRET.
One benefit of studying distances in single molecules is that heterogeneous populations can be studied more accurately with values specific for each molecule rather than computing an average based on an ensemble. This allows for the study of specific homogeneous populations within a heterogeneous population. For example, if two existing homologous populations within a heterogeneous population have different FRET values, an ensemble FRET analysis will produce a weighted averaged FRET value to represent the population as a whole. Thus, the obtained FRET value does not produce data on the two distinct populations. In contrast, smFRET would be able to differentiate between the two populations and would allow analysis of the existing homologous populations.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ha|first=Taekjip|date=2001-09-01|title=Single-Molecule Fluorescence Resonance Energy Transfer|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1046202301912174|journal=Methods|volume=25|issue=1|pages=78–86|doi=10.1006/meth.2001.1217}}</ref>
SmFRET also provides dynamic temporal resolution of an individual molecule that cannot be accomplished through ensemble FRET measurements. This allows smFRET to be used to study an [[RNA]]’s folding dynamics. Similar to [[protein folding]], RNA folding goes through multiple interactions, folding pathways, and intermediates before reaching its native state. Ensemble FRET has the ability to detect well-populated [[transition states]] that accumulate in a population, but it lacks the ability to characterize [[Reactive intermediate|intermediates]] that are short-lived and do not accumulate. This limit is addressed by smFRET which offers a direct way to observe the intermediates of single molecules regardless of accumulation. Therefore, smFRET demonstrates the ability to capture transient subpopulations in a heterogeneous environment.<ref>editors, Peter Hinterdorfer, Antoine van Oijen, (2009). ''Handbook of single-molecule biophysics'' (1. ed.). Dordrecht: Springer. {{ISBN|978-0-387-76497-9}}.</ref>
SmFRET is also shown to utilize a three-color system better than ensemble FRET. Using two acceptor fluorophores rather than one, FRET can observe multiple sites for correlated movements and spatial changes in any complex molecule. This is shown in the research on the [[Holliday Junction]]. SmFRET with the three-color system offers insights on synchronized movements of junction’s three helical sites and near non-existence of its parallel states. Ensemble FRET can use three-color system as well. However, any obvious advantages are outweighed by three-color system’s requirements which includes a clear separation of fluorophore signals. For a clear distinction of signal, FRET overlaps must be small but that also weakens FRET strength. SmFRET corrects its overlap limitations by using [[band-pass filters]] and [[dichroic filter|dichroic mirrors]] which further the signal between two fluorescence acceptors and solve for any bleed through effects.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hohng|first=Sungchul|last2=Joo|first2=Chirlmin|last3=Ha|first3=Taekjip|title=Single-Molecule Three-Color FRET|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0006349504736127|journal=Biophysical Journal|volume=87|issue=2|pages=1328–1337|doi=10.1529/biophysj.104.043935|pmc=1304471|pmid=15298935}}</ref>
== Applications == A major application of smFRET is to analyze the minute biochemical nuances that facilitate [[protein folding]]. In recent years, multiple techniques have been developed to investigate single molecule interactions that are involved in protein folding and unfolding. [[Kelvin probe force microscope|Force-probe techniques]], using [[atomic force microscopy]] and [[Optical tweezers|laser tweezers]], have provided information on protein stability. smFRET allows researchers to investigate molecular interactions using fluorescence. Forster resonance energy transfer (FRET) was first applied to single molecules by Ha et al. and applied to protein folding in work by Hochstrasser, Weiss, et al. The benefit that smFRET as a whole has afforded to analyzing molecular interactions is the ability to test single molecule interactions directly without having to average ensembles of data. In protein folding analysis, ensemble experiments involve taking measurements of multiple [[proteins]] that are in various states of transition between their [[Protein folding|folded and unfolded state]]. When averaged, the protein structure that can be inferred from the ensemble of data only provides a rudimentary structural model of protein folding. However, true understanding of protein folding requires deciphering the sequence of structural events along the folding pathways between the folded and unfolded states. It is this particular branch of research that smFRET is highly applicable.
FRET studies calculate corresponding FRET efficiencies as a result of time-resolved observation of [[protein folding]] events. These FRET efficiencies can then be used to infer distances between molecules as a function against time. As the protein transitions between the folded and unfolded states, the corresponding distances between molecules can indicate the sequence of molecular interactions that lead to protein folding.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schuler|first=Benjamin|last2=Eaton|first2=William A|date=2008-02-01|title=Protein folding studied by single-molecule FRET|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0959440X07002035|journal=Current Opinion in Structural Biology|series=Folding and Binding / Protein-nucleic acid interactions|volume=18|issue=1|pages=16–26|doi=10.1016/j.sbi.2007.12.003|pmc=2323684|pmid=18221865}}</ref>
Single-molecule FRET can also be applied to study the conformational changes of the relevant channel motifs in certain [[Ion channels|channels]]. For example, labeled tetrameric KirBac potassium channels were labeled with donor and acceptor [[fluorophores]] at particular sites in order to understand the structural dynamics within the [[lipid membrane]], thus allowing them to generalize similar dynamics for similar motifs in other [[eukaryotic]] Kir channels or even [[cation]] channels in general. The use of smFRET in this experiment allows for visualization of the conformational changes that cannot be seen if the macroscopic measurements are simply averaged. This will lead to ensemble analysis rather than analysis of individual molecules and the conformational changes within, allowing us to generalize similar dynamics for similar motifs in other [[eukaryotic]] channels.
The structural dynamics of the KirBac channel was thoroughly analyzed in both the open and closed states, dependent on the presence of the ligand [[PIP2]]. Part of the results based on smFRET demonstrated the structural rigidity of the [[extracellular]] region. The selectivity filter and the outer loop of the selectivity filter region was labeled with [[fluorophores]] and conformational coupling was observed. The individual smFRET trajectories strongly demonstrated a FRET efficiency of around 0.8 with no fluctuations, regardless of the state of the channel.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wang|first=Shizhen|last2=Vafabakhsh|first2=Reza|last3=Borschel|first3=William F|last4=Ha|first4=Taekjip|last5=Nichols|first5=Colin G|title=Structural dynamics of potassium-channel gating revealed by single-molecule FRET|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nsmb.3138|journal=Nature Structural & Molecular Biology|volume=23|issue=1|pages=31–36|doi=10.1038/nsmb.3138|pmc=4833211|pmid=26641713}}</ref>
== Limitations == Despite making approximate estimates, a limitation of smFRET is the difficulty of obtaining the correct distance involved in energy transfer. Requiring an accurate distance estimate gives rise to a major challenge because the fluorescence of the donor and acceptor fluorophores as well as the energy transfer is dependent on the environment and how the dyes are oriented, which can vary depending on the flexibility of where the fluorophores are bound. This issue, however, is not particularly relevant when the distance estimation of the two fluorophores does not need to be determined with exact and absolute precision.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Roy|first=Rahul|last2=Hohng|first2=Sungchul|last3=Ha|first3=Taekjip|title=A practical guide to single-molecule FRET|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nmeth.1208|journal=Nature Methods|volume=5|issue=6|pages=507–516|doi=10.1038/nmeth.1208|pmc=3769523|pmid=18511918}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=August 2015}}
The '''Sister Study''' is a nationwide effort, conducted by the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, one of the National Institutes of Health of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services to learn how the environment and genes may affect the chances of getting [[breast cancer]]. Over the next 10 years, the study will follow 50,000 sisters of women who have had breast cancer, in hopes of finding the environmental and genetic causes of the disease.
Sister Study participants are women ages 35 to 74. Women are eligible to participate if their sister (living or deceased), related to them by blood, had breast cancer; they have never had breast cancer themselves; and they live in the United States or Puerto Rico. The Sister Study is available in English and Spanish.
Organizations in partnership with the Sister Study include the [[American Cancer Society]], the Intercultural Cancer Council, the National Center on Minority Health and Health Disparities of the National Institutes of Health, Sisters Network Inc., [[Susan G. Komen for the Cure]], and [[Breast Cancer Network of Strength]].
== External links == * http://www.sisterstudy.org * http://www.estudiodehermanas.org * National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

{{Infobox book | name = The Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Numbers | title_orig = | translator = | image = Cover of 'The Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Numbers' (first edition).jpg | caption = Cover of the first edition | author = David Wells | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | subject = [[Recreational mathematics]], [[elementary number theory]] | genre = Non-fiction | publisher = [[Penguin Books]] | pub_date = 1986 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print ([[paperback]]) | pages = 229 pp ''(first edition)'' | isbn = 0-14-008029-5 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Numbers''''' is a [[reference book]] for [[recreational mathematics]] and [[elementary number theory]] written by David Wells. The first edition was published in paperback by [[Penguin Books]] in 1986 in the UK, and a revised edition appeared in 1997 ({{ISBN|0-14-026149-4}}).
==Contents== The entries are arranged in increasing order of magnitude, with the exception of the first entry on [[−1]] and [[Imaginary unit|''i'']]. The book includes some [[irrational number]]s below [[10 (number)|10]] but concentrates on [[integers]], and has an entry for every integer up to [[42 (number)|42]]. The final entry is for [[Graham's number]].
In addition to the dictionary itself, the book includes a [[list of mathematicians]] in chronological sequence (all born before 1890), a short [[glossary]], and a brief [[bibliography]]. The back of the book contains eight short tables "for the benefit of readers who cannot wait to look for their own patterns and properties", including lists of [[polygonal number]]s, [[Fibonacci number]]s, [[prime number]]s, [[factorial]]s, [[decimal fraction|decimal]] [[reciprocal (mathematics)|reciprocal]]s of primes, [[divisor|factor]]s of [[repunit]]s, and lastly the [[prime factorization]] and the values of the functions [[φ(n)|''φ''(''n'')]], [[divisor function|''d''(''n'') and ''σ''(''n'')]] for the first hundred integers. The book concludes with a conventional, [[alphabetical order|alphabetical]] [[index (publishing)|index]].
==Reviews== In a review of several books in The ''[[College Mathematics Journal]]'', [[Brian Blank]] described it as "a charming and interesting book",<ref>{{cite journal|last=Blank|first=Brian|authorlink=Brian Blank|title=Book Review|journal=The College Mathematics Journal|year=2001|volume=32|issue=2|pages=155–160|jstor=2687125}}</ref> and the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' described the revised edition as "a fascinating book on all things numerical".<ref>{{cite news|title=Reader's Guide. New in Paperback.|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/30167107.html?dids=30167107:30167107&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+14%2C+1998&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune|dead-url=yes|accessdate=2 June 2010|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=14 June 1998|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102113115/http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/30167107.html?dids=30167107:30167107&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+14,+1998&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune|archivedate=2 November 2012|df=}}</ref> By contrast, Christopher Hirst called it "a volume which none but [[wikt:propeller head|propeller-heads]] will find either curious or interesting" in a review of another book in ''[[The Independent]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hirst|first=Christopher|title=Thursday's Book: The Book of Numbers by William Hartston|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/thursdays-book-the-book-of-numbers-by-william-hartston-1289367.html|accessdate=2 June 2010|newspaper=The Independent|date=18 December 1997}}</ref>
==Style==
Beside the serious mathematics and [[number theory]], Wells occasionally makes humorous or playful comments on the numbers he is discussing. For example, his entry for the number [[39 (number)|39]] largely consists of a joke involving the [[interesting number paradox]]:
:'''39'''
:This appears to be the first uninteresting number, which of course makes it an especially interesting number, because it is the smallest number to have the property of being uninteresting.
:It is therefore also the first number to be simultaneously interesting and uninteresting. (pg. 120)
==See also== *[[On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences]]
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Numbers}} [[Category:Mathematics books]] [[Category:1986 books]] [[Category:Penguin Books books]]

{{Infobox book | name = The Physics of Star Trek | title_orig = | translator = | image = ThePhysicsofStarTrek.jpg | image_size = | author = [[Lawrence M. Krauss]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Physics and Star Trek]] | genre = [[Non-fiction]] | publisher = HarperPerennial | release_date = 1995 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]] and [[Paperback]]) | pages = 208 | isbn = 978-0-465-00559-8 | isbn_note= (hardcover)
{{ISBN|978-0-46-500204-7}} (revised and updated edition) | dewey = 791.45/72 20 | congress = QB500 .K65 1995 | oclc = 32925425 | preceded_by = [[Fear of Physics: A Guide for the Perplexed]] | followed_by = [[Beyond Star Trek]] }} '''''The Physics of Star Trek''''' is a 1995 non-fiction book by the [[theoretical physicist]] [[Lawrence M. Krauss]]. It is the third book by Krauss, who later wrote a followup titled ''[[Beyond Star Trek]]'' in 1997. ==Overview== Krauss discusses the [[physics]] involved in various concepts and objects described in the ''[[Star Trek]]'' universe. He investigates the possibility of such things as [[inertial damper]]s and [[warp drive (Star Trek)|warp drive]], and whether physics as we know it would allow such inventions. He also discusses [[time travel]], [[Speed of light|light speed]], pure [[energy being]]s, [[wormhole]]s, [[teleportation]], and other concepts that are staples of the ''[[Star Trek]]'' universe. The book includes a foreword by astrophysicist [[Stephen Hawking]]. ''The Physics of Star Trek'' was met with generally positive reviews. It became a national bestseller and sold more than 200,000 copies in the United States. As of 1998, it was being translated into 13 different languages. It was also the basis of a BBC television production.[http://www.jlab.org/news/news_letter/news_sep98/star_trek.html Journey through physics of Star Trek, real world with acclaimed physicist] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311035441/http://www.jlab.org/news/news_letter/news_sep98/star_trek.html |date=2007-03-11 }}, Jefferson Lab, "On Target" (September 1998), accessed November 2, 2006. Krauss got the idea for writing the book from his publisher, who initially suggested it as a joke. Krauss dismissed the idea but later thought that using ''Star Trek'' might get people interested in real physics.[http://www.vanderbilt.edu/register/articles?id=29589 Salisbury, David; 'The Physics of Star Trek' author to spend year on campus as visiting professor] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310231346/http://www.vanderbilt.edu/register/articles?id=29589 |date=2007-03-10 }}, ''[[Vanderbilt Register]]'', October 23, 2006. The hardcover edition was published in November 1995, and a paperback edition followed in September 1996. The book was revised and updated by Krauss in 2007. Krauss's next book, ''Beyond Star Trek: Physics from Alien Invasions to the End of Time'', was published in 1997. ==See also== * [[Physics and Star Trek|Physics and ''Star Trek'']] * ''[[Physics of the Impossible]]'' * ''[[The Physics of Superheroes]]'' * ''[[The Science of Star Wars (book)|The Science of Star Wars]]'' * ''[[The Science of Interstellar]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Memory Alpha|The Physics of Star Trek|''The Physics of Star Trek''}} * {{youtube|wMhrt8ZdkS0|Lawrence Krauss (2014) "The Physics of STAR TREK!"}} {{Star Trek publications}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Physics of Star Trek, The}} [[Category:1995 books]] [[Category:Physics books]] [[Category:Books about Star Trek]] [[Category:Books by Lawrence M. Krauss]]

revision.comment: I removed this sentence because, although it is linked to a published article, that article cannot back up its claim. I have done extensive research on this subject and have found no evidence that there was ever a 'Congressional ban' that was 'lifted' in 1969 or any other year. I contacted the author and editor of the article cited, and neither knows where that claim came from in their own article; it is likely based on a misremembered fact or an inaccurate rumor cited in an interview.
revision.text: {{Blacklisted-links|1= *https://womeninpolarsciencedotorg.files.wordpress.com/2015/12/womeninpolarscience-issueii.pdf *:''Triggered by \bfiles\.wordpress\.com\b on the global blacklist''|bot=Cyberbot II|invisible=true}} [[File:WAIS Divide Field Camp Woman.jpg|alt=Woman working at the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) Divide Field Camp in 2012.|thumb|300px|A woman working at the [[West Antarctic Ice Sheet]] (WAIS) Divide Field Camp in 2012.]] There have been '''women in [[Antarctica]]''' and exploring the regions around Antarctica for many centuries. [[Oral tradition]] of [[Māori people|Māori]] explorers reaching Antarctic waters as early as 650 CE, put women on the Antarctic map. The most celebrated "first" for women was in 1935 when [[Caroline Mikkelsen]] became the first woman to set foot on one of Antarctica's islands.[http://www.development.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0013/2092/Dr_Robin_Burns_Lecture_-_No._4.pdf "Women in Antarctica: Sharing this Life-Changing Experience"], transcript of speech by Robin Burns, given at the 4th Annual Phillip Law Lecture; Hobart, Tasmania, Australia; 18 June 2005. Retrieved 5 August 2010. Early male explorers, such as [[Richard E. Byrd|Richard Byrd]], named areas of Antarctica after wives and female heads of state.{{Sfn|Dodds|2009|p=506}} As Antarctica moved from a place of exploration and conquest to a scientific frontier, women worked to be included in the sciences. The first countries to have female scientists working in Antarctica were the [[Soviet Union]], [[South Africa]] and [[Argentina]].{{Cite news|url=http://mashable.com/2016/08/11/wikipedia-antarctic-women-scientists/#uLRJ0SaqRqqf|title=New Wikipedia Project Champions Women Scientists in the Antarctic|last=Bogle|first=Ariel|date=11 August 2016|work=Mashable|access-date=24 August 2016|via=}}{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.sun.ac.za/antarcticlegacy/about-2/sanae-iv/|title=SANAE IV|last=|first=|date=|work=Antarctic Legacy of South Africa|access-date=29 August 2016|via=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6418485//|title=Women Scientists Antarctica Bound|last=|first=|date=24 January 1969|work=Alamogordo Daily News|access-date=29 August 2016|via=Newspapers.com}} Besides exploring and working as scientists, women have also played supportive roles as wives, fund-raisers, publicists, historians, curators and administrators of organizations and services that support Antarctic operations.{{Sfn|Burns|2007|p=1092}} Many early women on Antarctica were the wives of explorers.{{Sfn|Burns|2001|p=11}} Some women worked with Antarctica from afar, crafting policies for a place they had never seen.{{Sfn|Dodds|2009|p=506}} Women who wished to have larger roles in Antarctica and on the continent itself had to "overcome gendered assumptions about the ice and surmount bureaucratic inertia.{{Sfn|Dodds|2009|p=508}} As women began to break into fields in Antarctica, they found that it could be difficult to compete against men who already had the "expeditioner experience" needed for permanent science positions.{{Sfn|Burns|2000|p=167}} Women who were qualified for expeditions or jobs in Antarctica were less likely to be selected than men, even after a 1995 study by Jane Mocellin showed that women cope better than men with the Antarctic environment.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dDRlAgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA108&dq=women%20antarctica&pg=PA89#v=onepage&q=women%20antarctica&f=false|title=Empire Antarctica: Ice, Silence, and Emperor Penguins|last=Francis|first=Gavin|publisher=Chatto & Windus|year=2012|isbn=9781619021846|location=Berkeley, CA|pages=89, 255|via=}} == Historic barriers against inclusion == [[File:Marie Byrd Land, West Antarctica by NASA.jpg|alt=Mary Byrd Land, named after the wife of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd in 1929.|thumb|Mary Byrd Land, named after the wife of Rear Admiral [[Richard E. Byrd]] in 1929.]] Most early policies and practices, including the construction and creation of Antarctic organizations were created initially by men.{{Sfn|Dodds|2009|p=505}} Women were originally excluded from early exploration in Antarctica based on the attitude that women could not handle the extremes in temperature or crisis situations.{{Cite web|url=http://www.exploratorium.edu/origins/antarctica/people/women.html|title=A Warmer Climate for Women in Antarctica|last=Hament|first=Ellyn|date=|website=Origins Antarctica: Scientific Journeys from McMurdo to the Pole|publisher=Exploratorium|access-date=24 August 2016}} [[Vivian Fuchs]], who was in charge of the [[British Antarctic Survey]] in the 1960s believed that women couldn't carry heavy equipment and that Antarctic facilities were unsuitable for women.{{Sfn|Lewander|2009|p=95}} The United States believed for many years that the [[climate]] of Antarctic was too harsh for women.{{Cite news|url=http://theinstitute.ieee.org/tech-history/technology-history/this-ieee-fellow-blazed-a-trail-for-female-scientists-in-antarctica|title=This IEEE Fellow Blazed a Trail for Female Scientists in Antarctica|last=Davis|first=Amanda|date=14 April 2016|work=The Institute|access-date=27 August 2016|via=}} Antarctica was seen by many men as a place where men could imagine themselves heroic conquerors. In [[Western culture]], frontier territories are often associated with [[masculinity]].{{Sfn|Collins|2009|p=515}} Antarctica itself was envisioned by many male explorers as a "[[Virginity|virginal]] woman" or "monstrous feminine body" to be conquered by men.{{Sfn|Blackadder|2015|p=170}} Women were often "invoked in terms of place naming and territorial conquest and later even encouraged to have babies in Antarctica."{{Sfn|Dodds|2009|p=505}} Using women as territorial conquest is probably at its most literal in the way that [[Argentina]] and [[Chile]] have flown pregnant women to Antarctica to give birth and stake a national claim to the area.{{Sfn|Dodds|2009|p=508}} Silvia Morella de Palma was the first woman to give birth in Antarctica, delivering 3.4 kg (7 lb 8 oz) [[Emilio Palma]] at the Argentine Esperanza base 7 January 1978. Men enjoyed having a space that was free of women and which in the late 1940s "allowed them to continue the kind of male companionship and adventure they had enjoyed during the [[World War II|Second World War]]."{{Sfn|Dodds|2009|p=507}} In one news article about Antarctica written in 1958, the writer describes the use of dazzlement: "On the womanless continent, the purpose of the dazzlement is not to catch the eye of a flirtatious blonde, but to attract spotters in the event that the explorers become lost in the frozen waste."{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6418278//|title=Womanless Continent of Snow and Cold|last=Montgomery|first=Ruth|date=1 November 1958|work=Lincoln Evening Journal|access-date=29 August 2016|via=Newspapers.com}} Men's spaces in Antarctica resisted change. In the 1980s, there was an attempt by men to memorialize the "Sistine ceiling" of the Weddell hut in Antarctica as an [[Australians|Australian]] national heritage site of "high significance." The "Sistine ceiline" was covered in 92 different [[Pornography|pornographic]] [[Pin-up model|pinups]] of women from the 1970s and 1980s.{{Sfn|Collins|2009|p=516}} This represented a "male's only club" in which participants believed women would spoil the "purity of a [[Homosociality|homosocial]] work--and play--environment."{{Cite journal|last=Glasberg|first=Elena|date=2011|title='Living Ice': Rediscovery of the Poles in an Era of Climate Crisis|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/457583|journal=Women's Studies Quarterly|volume=39|issue=3|pages=229–230|doi=|pmid=|access-date=|subscription=yes|via=Project MUSE}} In 1983, the ''[[The San Bernardino Sun|San Bernardino County Sun]]'' newspaper published an article about Antarctica stating that it "is still one of the last [[Machismo|macho]] redoubts, where men are men and women are superfluous."{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6417901//|title=Women Who Conquer the South Pole|last=Satchell|first=Michael|date=5 June 1983|work=The San Bernardino County Sun|access-date=29 August 2016|via=Newspapers.com}} One scientist, Lyle McGinnis, who had been going to Antarctica since 1957 resented women in the field, saying that "men never grouse," but he believed that women complained and needed "comfort."{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6417980//|title=Women Who Conquer the South Pole (continued)|last=Satchell|first=Michael|date=5 June 1983|work=The San Bernardino County Sun|access-date=29 August 2016|via=Newspapers.com}} Not all men felt that way. Other men felt that women's presence made life in Antarctica better and one male engineer stated that without women around, "men are pigs."{{Sfn|Legler|2004|p=37}} Sociologist [[Charles Moskos]] stated that as more women are introduced to a group, there is less [[aggression]] and a "more civil culture develops."{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/10/science/after-struggle-women-win-place-ice-labs-field-new-outlook.html?pagewanted=1|title=After a Struggle, Women Win A Place 'on the Ice'; In Labs and in the Field, a New Outlook|last=Dean|first=Cornelia|date=10 November 1998|work=The New York Times|access-date=30 August 2016|via=}} Many of the careers in Antarctica are in the sciences, and women faced barriers there as well. As women attempted to work in science, arguments using [[biological determinism]], [[evolutionary psychology]] and popular notions of [[Neuroscience|neurobiology]] were used as excuses as to why there were fewer women in the sciences.{{Sfn|Hulbe, Wang & Ommanney|2010|p=960}} These arguments described how "women are ill-adapted on evolutionary grounds for science and the competitive environment of the laboratory."{{Sfn|Hulbe, Wang & Ommanney|2010|p=960}} Some women described feeling that they were "a bit of a joke" working in Antarctica, and felt that men regarded them as incapable.{{Sfn|Burns|2000|p=173}} Antarctic exploration and science research was often facilitated by national [[Navy|navies]], who often did not want women on their ships.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PYdBH4dOOM4C&lpg=PA309&ots=hdG-wMxuhj&dq=%22silvia%20morello%20de%20palma%22&pg=PA716#v=onepage&q=woman&f=false|title=Exploring Polar Frontiers: A Historical Encyclopedia|last=Mills|first=William James|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2003|isbn=9781576074220|volume=1|location=Santa Barbara, CA|pages=716–717|via=}} The [[United States Navy]] used the excuse that "sanitation facilities were too primitive" on Antarctica as an excuse to bar women. The U.S. Navy also considered Antarctica a "male-only bastion."{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/discoveries/disc_summ.jsp?cntn_id=116134|title=The First Women in Antarctica|last=|first=|date=11 January 2010|website=National Science Foundation|publisher=|access-date=24 August 2016}} Admiral [[George J. Dufek|George Dufek]] said in 1956 that "women would join American Teams in the Antarctic over his dead body."{{Cite web|url=http://www.theantarcticbookofcookingandcleaning.com/antarctic-women.html|title=Antarctic Women Then & Now|last=|first=|date=|website=The Antarctic Book of Cooking and Cleaning|publisher=|access-date=27 August 2016}} He also believed that women's presence on Antarctica "would wreck men's illusions of being heroes and frontiersmen."{{Sfn|Lewander|2009|p=95}} Military groups also were worried about "[[sexual misconduct]]." As women began to try to become part of Antarctic exploration and research, change was slow.{{Sfn|Burns|2001|p=12}} An article run in ''[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|The Daily Herald]]'' newspaper of [[Chicago]] in 1974 described women finally coming to Antarctica as integrating the "land with a definite feminine touch."{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6418381//|title=Women in Antarctic|last=Miller|first=Robert C.|date=11 February 1974|work=The Daily Herald|access-date=29 August 2016|via=Newspapers.com}} The article describes women's perfumed smells, ways of entertaining guests on Antarctica and the "dainty feet" of [[Caroline Mikkelsen]]. Eventually, however, both the "presence and impact of female Antarctic researchers has increased rapidly."{{Cite web|url=http://www.scar.org/women|title=Celebrating Women in Antarctic Research|last=|first=|date=|website=The Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research|publisher=|access-date=27 August 2016}} == Early women involved in Antarctica == [[File:Ingrid Christensen and Mathilde Wegger on voyage in 1931.jpg|alt=Ingrid Christensen (left) and Mathilde Wegger on a voyage in 1931.|thumb|[[Ingrid Christensen]] (left) and Mathilde Wegger on a voyage in 1931.]] Oral records from [[Oceania]] indicate that women explorers, [[Ui-te-Rangiora|Ui-te-rangiora]] around 650 CE and Te Ara-tanga-nuku in 1000 CE, may have traveled to the Antarctic regions.{{Sfn|Hulbe, Wang & Ommanney|2010|p=947}} The first Western woman to visit the Antarctic region was [[Louise Seguin|Louise Séguin]], who sailed on the ''Roland'' with [[Yves-Joseph de Kerguelen-Trémarec|Yves Joseph de Kerguelen]] in 1773.{{Sfn|Hulbe, Wang & Ommanney|2010|p=947}} In the early [[20th century|twentieth century]], women were interested in going to Antarctica. When [[Ernest Shackleton]] advertised his 1914 Antarctic expedition, three women wrote to him, requesting to join, though the women never became part of the journey.{{Sfn|Blackadder|2015|p=170}} In 1919, newspapers reported that women wanted to go to Antarctica, writing that "several women were anxious to join, but their applications were refused."{{Sfn|Blackadder|2015|p=171}} Later, in 1929, twenty-five women applied to the [[British Australian and New Zealand Antarctic Research Expedition|British, Australian and New Zealand Antarctic Research Expedition]] (BANZARE), and were also rejected.{{Sfn|Blackadder|2015|p=171}} When a British Antarctic Expedition was proposed in 1937, 1,300 women applied to join.{{Sfn|Blackadder|2015|p=171}} None of those 1,300 went to the frozen continent. Women who were wives of explorers who were left behind "endured years of loneliness and anxiety."{{Cite journal|last=Roldan|first=Gabriela|date=2010|title=Changes in the Contributions of Women to Antarctic National Programmes|url=http://www.anta.canterbury.ac.nz/documents/PCAS_13/Roldan%20G%20Review.pdf|journal=PCAS 13 Review|volume=|issue=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=30 August 2016|hdl=10092/13909}} Women like Kathleen Scott raised money for their husbands' journeys. The first women involved in exploration of Antarctica were wives and companions of male travelers and explorers. Women accompanied men as "whaling wives" to Antarctic waters.{{Sfn|Lewander|2009|p=90}} The first women to see the continent of Antarctica was Norwegian [[Ingrid Christensen]] and her companion, Mathilde Wegger, both of whom were traveling with Christensen's husband.{{Sfn|Blackadder|2015|p=172}} The first woman to step onto the land of Antarctica, an [[island]], was [[Caroline Mikkelsen]] in 1935. Mikkelsen only briefly went ashore, and was also there with her husband.{{Sfn|Walker|2013|p=17}} Later, after her husband died, Mikkelsen remarried and didn't talk about her experience in Antarctica in order "to spare his feelings."{{Sfn|Blackadder|2015|p=173-174}} Christensen went back to Antarctica three times after she first glimpsed the land.{{Sfn|Blackadder|2015|p=174}} She eventually landed at [[Scullin monolith|Scullin Monolith]], becoming the first woman to set foot on the Antarctic mainland, followed by her daughter, Augusta Sofie Christensen, and two other women: [[Lillemor Rachlew]], and Solveig Widerøe.{{Cite web|url=http://www.antarctica.gov.au/magazine/2011-2015/issue-23-december-2012/antarctic-arts-fellowship/the-first-woman-in-antarctica|title=The first woman in Antarctica|date=2012|website=www.antarctica.gov.au|publisher=Australian Antarctic Division|language=en-au|access-date=2016-06-27}}{{Cite journal|last=Jesse|first=Blackadder,|date=2013-01-01|title=Illuminations : casting light upon the earliest female travellers to Antarctica|url=http://researchdirect.uws.edu.au/islandora/object/uws:22583}}Bogen, H. (1957). ''Main events in the history of Antarctic exploration''. Sandefjord: Norwegian Whaling Gazette, page 85 Because the women believed the landing wasn't an actual "first," they didn't make much of their accomplishment.{{Sfn|Blackadder|2015|p=174}} In the years of 1946 and 1947, [[Jackie Ronne]] and [[Jennie Darlington]] were the first women to spend the year in Antarctica.{{Cite web|url=http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/features/contentHandler.cfm?id=1954|title=Famous Firsts|last=|first=|date=13 November 2009|website=The Antarctic Sun|publisher=United States Antarctic Program|access-date=25 August 2016}} When Ronne and Darlington decided to accompany their husbands in 1946 to Antarctica, men on the expedition "signed a petition trying to stop it happening."{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WMa5n9ZAV4YC&lpg=PA10&dq=first%20women%20antarctica&pg=PA10#v=onepage&q=first%20women%20antarctica&f=false|title=Mountains of Madness: A Scientist's Odyssey in Antarctica|last=Long|first=John|publisher=Joseph Henry Press|year=2001|isbn=0309070775|location=Washington, D.C.|pages=10|via=}} Ronne worked as the mission's "recorder."{{Sfn|Burns|2001|p=15}} Ronne and Darlington both wrote about their experiences on the ice, and in the case of Darlington's book, about how conflict between team members also "strained relations between the two women."{{Sfn|Rothblum, Weinstock & Morris|1998|p=2}} One of the ways that Darlington tried to fit in with the men of the group was to make herself as "inconspicuous within the group as possible."{{Cite journal|last=Aston|first=Felicity|date=September 2005|title=Women of the White Continent|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=18007340&site=ehost-live|journal=Geographical (Campion Interactive Publishing)|volume=77|issue=9|page=26|doi=|pmid=|access-date=25 August 2016|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}} One man, first seeing Darlington arrive at the Antarctic base, "fled in fright, thinking that he'd gone mad." Both women, upon returning from Antarctica downplayed their own roles, letting "their husbands take most of the honour."{{Sfn|Lewander|2009|p=93}} In 1948, the British diplomat, [[Margaret Anstee]], was involved in the [[Falkland Islands Dependencies|Falkland Islands Dependency]] Survey (FIDS) and helped make policy for the program.{{Sfn|Dodds|2009|p=506}} == Further exploration and science == [[File:Irene Bernasconi - Las investigadoras en la Base Esperanza 1968.jpg|alt=Irene Bernasconi and others in 1968 at Esperanza Base.|thumb|[[Irene Bernasconi]] and others in 1968 at Esperanza Base]] Women scientists first began researching Antarctica from ships. The first woman scientist, [[Maria Klenova|Maria V. Klenova]] of the [[Soviet Union]], worked on the ships ''Ob'' and ''Lena'' just off the Antarctic coastline in 1955 to 1956.{{Sfn|Burns|2007|p=1094}} Klenova's work helped create the first Antarctic [[Atlas (geography)|atlas]]. Women served on Soviet Union ships going to Antarctica after 1963.{{Sfn|Burns|2007|p=1094}} The first women to visit a US station and the first to fly to Antarctica were [[First women to fly to Antarctica|Pat Hepinstall and Ruth Kelley]], Pan Am flight attendants, who spent four hours on the ground at the [[McMurdo Station]] on October 15, 1957.{{cite web|url=http://www.panam.org/images/Stories/Pan-Am-Way-Down-South.pdf|title=Pan Am: Way Down South|publisher=Pan Am Historical Foundation|access-date=9 September 2016 |language=}} Often women going to Antarctica had to be approved in both official and unofficial ways. An early candidate for becoming one of the first women scientists to go to Antarctica was [[geologist]] Dawn Rodley, who had been approved of not only by the expedition sponsor, Colin Bull, but also by the wives of the male team-members.{{Cite web|url=http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/features/contentHandler.cfm?id=1955|title=Behind the Scenes|last=Bull|first=Colin|date=13 November 2009|website=The Antarctic Sun|publisher=United States Antarctic Program|access-date=25 August 2016}} Rodley was set to go in 1958, but the [[United States Navy]], who were in charge of [[Operation Deep Freeze]], refused to take her to Antarctica. The Navy decided that sending a four-woman team would be acceptable, and Bull began to build a team including [[Lois Jones (scientist)|Lois Jones]], Kay Lindsay, [[McSaveney Spur|Eileen McSaveney]] and Terry Tickhill. These four women were part of the group who became the first women to visit the [[South Pole]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.southpolestation.com/trivia/igy2/welch/jones.html|title=First Women at Pole|last=|first=|date=|website=South Pole Station|publisher=|access-date=24 August 2016}} Jones's team worked mainly in [[Wright Valley]]. After their return, Bull found that several of his male friends resented the addition of women and even called him a "traitor". The first United States all-female team was led by Jones in 1969. Her team, which included the first women to set foot on the South Pole, were used by the navy as a publicity stunt, "paraded around" and called "Powderpuff explorers".{{Sfn|Legler|2004|p=36}} The first United States woman to step into in the Antarctic interior in 1970 was engineer [[Irene C. Peden|Irene C Peden]], who also faced various barriers to her working on the continent.{{Sfn|Peden|1998|p=17}} Peden describes how a "mythology had been created about the women who'd gone to the coast -- that they had been a problem," and that since they had not published their work within the year, they were "heavily criticized."{{Sfn|Peden|1998|p=18}} Men in the Navy in charge of approving her trip to Antarctica were "dragging their feet", citing that there were not women's bathrooms available and that without another female companion, she would not be allowed to go.{{Sfn|Peden|1998|p=19}} The admiral in charge of transportation to Antarctica suggested that Peden was trying to go there for adventure, or to find a husband, rather than for her research. Despite her setbacks, including not receiving critical equipment in Antarctica, Peden's research on the continent was successful. [[File:Ursula B. Marvin in Antarctica.jpg|alt=Ursula B. Marvin in Antarctica, 1978-1979|thumb|[[Ursula B. Marvin]] in Antarctica, 1978–1979]] The first U.S. woman to run an Antarctic research station was [[Mary Alice McWhinnie]], who led the [[McMurdo Station]] in 1974 and was accompanied by a [[nun]] and biologist, [[Mary Odile Cahoon]].{{Sfn|Legler|2004|p=36}} United States women in 1978 were still using equipment and [[Extreme Cold Weather Clothing|arctic clothing]] designed for men, although "officials said that problem is being quickly remedied." American Ann Peoples became the manager of the Berg Field Center in 1986, becoming the first woman to serve in a "significant leadership role". [[British people|British]] women had similar problems to the Americans. The director of the [[British Antarctic Survey]] (BAS) from 1959 to 1973 was [[Vivian Fuchs]], who "firmly believed that the inclusion of women would disrupt the harmony and scientific productivity of Antarctic stations." British women scientists started working on curating collections as part of the BAS prior to being allowed to visit Antarctica. Women who applied to the BAS were discouraged. A letter from BAS personnel sent to a woman who applied in the 1960s read, "Women wouldn't like it in Antarctica as there are no shops and no hairdresser."{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/environment/9260864/Women-wont-like-working-in-Antarctica-as-there-are-no-shops-and-hairdressers.html|title='Women Won't Like Working in Antarctica as There are No Shops and Hairdressers'|last=Jones|first=Beth|date=20 May 2012|work=The Telegraph|access-date=25 August 2016|via=}} The first BAS woman to go to Antarctica was [[Janet Thomson]] in 1983 who described the ban on women as a "rather improper segregation."{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/hilarybrueck/2016/02/13/antarctica-homeward-bound/#aaac67c7642b|title=Meet the All-Women Team heading to Antarctica This Year|last=Brueck|first=Hilary|date=13 February 2016|work=Forbes|access-date=27 August 2016|via=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/voices-of-science/interviewees/janet-thomson/audio/janet-thomson-an-improper-segregation-of-scientists-at-the-british-antarctic-survey|title=Janet Thomson: An 'Improper Segregation of Scientists' at the British Antarctic Survey|last=|first=|date=|website=Voices of Science|publisher=British Library|access-date=27 August 2016}} Women were still effectively barred from using UK bases and logistics in 1987.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IkGUyj9GI18C&lpg=PA230&dq=women%20antarctica&pg=PA230#v=onepage&q=women%20antarctica&f=false|title=Horizons in Physical Geology|last=Sugden|first=David|publisher=Barnes & Noble Books|year=1987|isbn=0389207527|editor-last=Clark|editor-first=Michael J.|location=Totowa, NJ|pages=230|chapter=The Polar and Glacial World|editor-last2=Gregory|editor-first2=Kenneth J.|editor-last3=Gurnell|editor-first3=Angela M.|via=}} Women didn't winter-over at the [[Halley Research Station]] until 1996, forty years after the British station was established. [[Argentina]] sent four women scientists – biologist [[Irene Bernasconi]], [[Bacteriology|bacteriologist]] Maria Adela Caria, biologist Elena Martinez Fontes and algae expert [[Carmen Pujals]] – to Antarctica in 1969. Later, in 1978, Argentina sent a pregnant woman, Silvia Morello de Palma, to the [[Esperanza Base]] to give birth and to "use the baby to stake [their] territorial claims" to Antarctica.{{Cite web|url=http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/how-a-baby-staked-argentina-s-claim-on-antarctica|title=How a Baby Staked Argentina's Claim on Antarctica|last=Holmes|first=Tao Tao|date=25 February 2016|website=Atlas Obscura|publisher=|access-date=29 August 2016}} Once [[Australia]] opened up travel to Antarctica to women, [[Elizabeth Chipman]], who first worked as a typist at Casey Station in 1976, chronicled all of the women to travel there up to 1984.{{Sfn|Blackadder|2013|p=90}} Chipman worked to find the names of all women who had ever been to or even near Antarctica and eventually donated 19 folio boxes of her research to the [[National Library of Australia]].{{Sfn|Blackadder|2013|p=90}}{{Cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.ms-ms9635|title=Guide to the Papers of Elizabeth Chipman|last=|first=|date=|website=National Library of Australia|publisher=|access-date=30 August 2016}} == Women gain ground == [[File:Dr. In-Young Ahn at the Korean Antarctic Station, King Sejong in October 2015.jpg|thumb|[[In-Young Ahn]] at [[King Sejong Station]] in Antarctica in 2015.]] The [[National Science Foundation]] (NSF) started long-range planning in 1978, looking towards facilities that could accommodate a population made up of 25% women.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/6418753//|title=Women in Antarctica: No Longer Frozen Out|last=Hudson|first=Ken|date=13 January 1978|work=Santa Cruz Sentinel|access-date=29 August 2016|via=Newspapers.com}} In the 1979-1980 season, there were only 43 women on the continent.{{Sfn|Rothblum, Weinstock & Morris|1998|p=5}} By 1981, there were nearly one woman for every ten men in Antarctica.{{Cite web|url=http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/features/contentHandler.cfm?id=1951|title=Women Fully Integrated Into USAP Over Last 40 Years|last=Rejcek|first=Peter|date=13 November 2009|website=The Antarctic Sun|publisher=United States Antarctic Program|access-date=25 August 2016}} In 1983, the ratio was back to 20 men for every woman. In the 1980s, [[Susan Solomon|Susan Solomon's]] research in Antarctica on the [[ozone layer]] and the "ozone hole" causes her to gain "fame and acclaim."{{Sfn|Rossiter|2012|p=179}} In [[Spain]], [[Josefina Castellví]], helped coordinate and also participated in her country's expedition to Antarctica in 1984.{{Cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/ciencia/2013/12/01/529901a80ab740ed668b456e.html|title=La abuela científica regresa a la Antártida|last=Guerrero|first=Teresa|date=12 June 2013|work=El Mundo|language=Spanish|access-date=29 August 2016|via=}} Later, after a Spanish base was constructed in 1988, Castellví was put in charge after the leader, Antoni Ballester had a stroke. The first female station leader on Antarctica is Australian, [[Diana Patterson]], head of [[Mawson Station]] in 1989.{{Cite journal|last=Blackadder|first=Jesse|date=2013|title=Heroines of the Ice|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=86031010&site=ehost-live|journal=Australian Geographic|volume=|issue=113|doi=|pmid=|access-date=29 August 2016|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}} The first all-female over-wintering group is from [[Germany]] and spends the 1990-1991 winter at [[Neumayer-Station II|Georg von Neumayer]], with the first German female station leader and medical doctor [[Monika Puskeppeleit]].{{Sfn|Burns|2007|p=1095}} In 1991 [[In-Young Ahn]] is the first female leader of an [[Asia]]n research station ([[King Sejong Station]]), and the first [[South Korea]]n woman to step onto Antarctica.{{Cite journal|last=Havermans|first=Charlotte|date=December 2015|title=Interview With the Station Leader of the South Korean Research Base King Sejong in Antarctica: Dr. In-Young Ahn|url=https://womeninpolarsciencedotorg.files.wordpress.com/2015/12/womeninpolarscience-issueii.pdf|journal=Women in Polar Science|volume=|issue=2|pages=8–13|doi=|pmid=|access-date=25 August 2016|via=}} There were approximately 180 women in Antarctica in the 1990-1991 season.{{Sfn|Rothblum, Weinstock & Morris|1998|p=5}} Women from several different countries were regularly members of over-wintering teams by 1992.{{Sfn|Burns|2007|p=1095}} The first all-women expedition reached the South Pole in 1993.{{Sfn|Legler|2004|p=37}} [[Diana Patterson]], the first female station leader on Antarctica, saw a change happening in 1995. She felt that many of the sexist views of the past had given way so that women were judged not by the fact that they were women, but "by how well you did your job."{{Sfn|Blackadder|2013|p=92}} [[Social science|Social scientist]], Robin Burns, studied the social structures of Antarctica in the 1995-1996 season. She found that while many earlier women struggled, in 1995, there was more acceptance of women in Antarctica.{{Sfn|Blackadder|2013|p=94}} Also by the mid 1990s, one of the station managers, Ann Peoples, felt that a [[Tipping point (sociology)|tipping point]] had been reached and women on Antarctica became more normalized. There were still men in Antarctica who were not afraid to voice their opinion that women should not "be on the ice," but many others enjoyed having "women as colleagues and friends."{{Sfn|Walker|2013|p=19-20}} Women around this time began to feel like it was "taken for granted now that women go to the Antarctic." Studies done in the early 2000s showed that women's inclusion in Antarctic groups were beneficial overall.{{Cite journal|last=Tafforin|first=Carole|date=2009|title=Life at the Franco-Italian Concordia Station in Antarctica for a Voyage to Mars: Ethological Study and Anthropological Perspectives|url=http://www.antrocom.net/upload/sub/antrocom/050109/08-Antrocom.pdf|journal=Atntrocom|volume=5|issue=1|page=71|doi=|pmid=|access-date=28 August 2016|via=}} In the early 2000s, Robin Burns has found that female scientists who enjoyed their experience in Antarctica were ones who were able to finish their scientific work, to see through the project into completion.{{Sfn|Burns|2000|p=171}} == Recent history == [[File:Women at 2013 Icestock.jpg|alt=Women celebrate at 2013 Icestock in Antarctica.|thumb|Women celebrate at 2013 Icestock in Antarctica.]] In 2005, writer Gretchen Legler describes how there were many more women in Antarctica that year and that some are [[lesbian]]s.{{Cite journal|last=Marler|first=Regina|date=2005|title=Ice Queen|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=19049705&site=ehost-live|journal=Advocate|volume=|issue=952|page=77|doi=|pmid=|access-date=29 August 2016|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}} [[International Women's Day]] in 2012 saw more than fifty women celebrating in Antarctica and who made up 70% of the International Antarctic Expedition.{{Sfn|Verbitsky|2015|p=59}} In 2013, when the [[Netherlands]] opened their first Antarctic Lab, [[Corina Brussaard]] was there to help set it up.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dw.com/en/women-climate-scientists-conquer-antarctica/a-16650017|title=Women Climate Scientists Conquer Antarctica|last=Postma|first=Laura|date=3 June 2013|work=DW|last2=Coelho|first2=Saroja|access-date=27 August 2016|via=}} [https://homewardboundprojects.com.au/ Homeward Bound], is a 10 year program designed to encourage women's participation in science that planned to send the first large (78 member) all-women expedition to Antarctica in 2016.{{Cite news|url=http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/78-Women-Go-to-Antarctica-to-Spread-Word-About-Climate-Change-20160729-0038.html|title=78 Women Go to Antarctica to Spread Word About Climate Change|last=|first=|date=29 July 2016|work=TeleSUR|access-date=27 August 2016|via=}} The first group consisted of 76 women and arrived in Antarctica for three weeks in December of 2016.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bustle.com/p/how-networking-in-antarctica-could-give-women-in-stem-fields-the-ultimate-advantage-47420|title=How Networking In Antarctica Could Give Women In STEM Fields The Ultimate Advantage|last=Spychalsky|first=Alexandra|work=Bustle|access-date=2017-12-06|language=en}} Fabian Dattner and [[Jessica Melbourne-Thomas|Jess Melbourne-Thomas]] founded the project and the Dattner Grant is providing funding, with each participant contributing $15,000 to the project.{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/women-in-science-journey-to-antarctica-in-fight-to-save-the-planet-20160714-gq5epc.html|title=Women in Science Journey to Antarctica in Fight to Save the Planet|last=Choahan|first=Neelima|date=16 July 2016|work=The Age|access-date=27 August 2016|via=}} Homeward bound includes businesswomen and scientists who look at [[climate change]] and women's leadership. The plan is to create a network of 1,000 women who will become leaders in the sciences. The first voyage departed South America in December 2016 {{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/homeward-bound-trip-to-take-78-female-leaders-in-science-to-antarctica-20150924-gjuhx9.html|title=Women in Science: Homeward Bound's Voyage to Antarctica Focuses on Climate Change|last=Cormack|first=Lucy|date=26 September 2015|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=27 August 2016|via=}} An all-woman team of [[British Army|United Kingdom Army]] soldiers, called Exercise Ice Maiden, started recruiting members in 2015 to attempt to cross the continent under their own power in 2017.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=November 2015|title=Women Set for Epic Trek|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=f5h&AN=111413782&site=ehost-live|journal=Soldiers|volume=71|issue=11|page=15|doi=|pmid=|access-date=24 August 2016|subscription=yes|via=EBSCOhost}} If successful, they will be the first military group of women to do so. Exercise Ice Maiden is meant to study "female endurance in extreme conditions."{{Cite news|url=http://forces.tv/39098245|title=Meet the Army's Ice Maidens|last=Knox|first=Julie|date=1 October 2015|work=Forces TV|access-date=24 August 2016|via=}} Currently, women make up 55% of membership in the [[Association of Polar Early Career Scientists]] (APECS). In 2016, nearly a third of all researchers at the South Pole were women. The [[Australian Antarctic Division|Australian Antarctic Program]] (AAP) makes a "conscious effort to recruit women."{{Sfn|Verbitsky|2015|p=58}} A social media network has recently been created "Women in Polar Science" it aims to connect women working in Arctic and Antarctic science and provides them with a platform to share an exchange knowledge, experiences and opportunities. == Sexual harassment and sexism == When heavy equipment operator, Julia Uberuaga, first went to Antarctica in the late 70s, early 80s, she recalled that "the men stared at her, or leered at her, or otherwise let her know she was unwelcome on the job." Rita Matthews, who went to Antarctica during the same period as Uberuaga said that the "men were all over the place. There were some that would never stop going after you." In 1983, Marilyn Woody described living at McMurdo station and said, "It makes your head spin, all this attention from all these men." Then she said, "You realize you can put a bag over your head and they'll still fall in love with you." Another scientist, Cynthia McFee, had been completely shut out of the "male camaraderie" at her location and had to deal with loneliness for long periods of time. Martha Kane, the second woman to overwinter at the South Pole, experienced "negative pressure" by the men with "some viewing her as an interloper who had insinuated herself into a male domain." In the 1990s, women experienced stigma in Antarctica. These women were labeled "[[Prostitution|whores]]" for interacting with men and those who did not interact with men were called "[[Dyke (slang)|dykes]]."{{Sfn|Rothblum, Weinstock & Morris|1998|p=12}} In the late 1990s and early 2000s, women felt that Antarctic operations were "not at all sympathetic to the needs of mothers, and there is a deep concern lest a pregnant woman give birth in Antarctica."{{Sfn|Burns|2000|p=168}} [[Sexual harassment]] is still a problem for women working in Antarctica, with many women scientists fielding unwanted sexual advances over and over again.{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-05-05/women-scientists-in-antarctica-report-sexual-harassment/6443570|title=Stories of Sexual Harassment Against Women in Antarctica Highlight Issue in Science Industry|last=Hague|first=Brietta|date=4 May 2015|work=ABC News|access-date=24 August 2016|via=}} Women continue to be outnumbered in many careers in Antarctica, including fleet operations and [[Tradesman|trades]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.transitionsabroad.com/publications/magazine/0005/women_working_in_antartica.shtml|title=Women Working on Ice|last=Williams|first=Lisa Ann|date=|website=Transitions Abroad|publisher=|access-date=25 August 2016}} Some organizations, such as the Australian Antarctic Division, have created and adopted policies in order to combat sexual harassment and discrimination based on gender.{{Sfn|Blackadder|2013|p=94}} The [[United States Antarctic Program]] (USAP) encourages women and minorities to apply.{{Cite web|url=http://www.usap.gov/jobsAndOpportunities/|title=Jobs and Opportunities|last=|first=|date=|website=United States Antarctic Program|publisher=|access-date=30 August 2016}} == Women record-breakers == American Lisa Densmore is the first woman to summit [[Vinson Massif|Mount Vinson]] in 1988.{{Cite news|url=http://www.livescience.com/41122-mount-vinson-antarcticas-highest-mountain.html|title=Mount Vinson: Antarctica's Highest Mountain|last=Zimmermann|first=Kim Ann|date=11 November 2013|work=Live Science|access-date=30 August 2016|via=}} In 1993, American [[Ann Bancroft]] lead the first all woman expedition to the South Pole.{{Cite web|url=http://www.livescience.com/31297-extreme-female-explorers.html|title=7 Extreme Explorers|last=Gammon|first=Katharine|date=28 March 2012|website=Live Science|publisher=|access-date=24 August 2016}} Bancroft, and [[Norway|Norwegian]], [[Liv Arnesen]] were the first women to ski across Antarctica in 2001. [[Lynne Cox]] swam a mile in Antarctic water in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/02/12/60II/main540357.shtml|title=Swimming to America|last=McKay|first=Mary-Jayne|publisher=CBS News|work=60 Minutes|accessdate=21 July 2011|archiveurl=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/02/12/60II/main540357.shtml|archivedate=Feb 12, 2003}} [[Maria Leijerstam]] became the first person to cycle to the [[South Pole Station]] in 2013 on a [[recumbent tricyle]].{{citation|title = British adventurer Maria Leijerstam achieves world first by cycling to South Pole|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/british-adventurer-maria-leijerstam-achieves-world-first-by-cycling-to-south-pole-9026928.html|newspaper= [[The Independent]]|accessdate = 2015-11-04|language = en}} == Honors and awards == In 1975, [[Eleanor Honnywill]] becomes the first woman to be awarded the [[Fuchs Medal]] from the [[British Antarctic Survey]] (BAS).{{Sfn|Burns|2007|p=1095}} The first woman to receive a [[Polar Medal]] was [[Ginny Fiennes|Virginia Fiennes]], in 1986, who was honored for her work in the [[Transglobe Expedition]].{{Sfn|Burns|2007|p=1095}} She was also the first woman to "winter in both polar regions." Denise Allen is the first woman awarded the [[Australian Antarctic Medal]] in 1989.{{Sfn|Burns|2007|p=1095}} == See also == {{portal|Antarctica}} * [[Arctic exploration]] * [[European and American
